article:
'Greasestock' is an American event held yearly in Yorktown Heights, New York. It
is one of the largest alternative fuel, renewable energy, and low-energy green
vehicle exhibitions in the United States. Norman, Jim. "[http://www.nytimes-
.com/2007/05/13/automobiles/13GREASE.html?_r=1&partner=rssnyt&emc=rss&oref=slog-
in Where Thereâs Never an Oil Shortage]". [[New York Times]]. May 13,
2007. Exhibitors showcase a variety of alternative energy vehicles, as
well as exhibits with a sustainable lifestyle
theme. "[http://www.greasestock.org/ Greasestock 2008]".
[http://greasestock.org Greasestock]. Retrieved May 20, 2008. Although it
is illegal in New York to power a vehicle with waste vegetable oil(the Federal
Clean Air Act of 1990 forbids the use of non-compliant biodiesels such as raw
vegetable oil, this is illegal nationwide, not just in New York), authorities in
New York have stated they have no problem with the festival and have even
participated in it. Tillman, Adriane.
"[http://northcountynews.com/Apps/FullSize.aspx?articleid=4034 Greasestock
Festival returns, bigger and better]". [http://northcountynews.com North County
News]. May 14, 2008.

The event was founded in 2003 by individuals who shared an interest in vegetable
powered vehicles. Max, Josh. "[http://www.nydailynews.com/autos/2008/05/13/2008-05-
13_gasguzzlers_become_veggie_delights_at_gr.html Gas-guzzlers become veggie
delights at Greasestock in Yorktown Heights]". [[Daily News (New York)|NY Daily
News]]. May 13, 2008. It held on the grounds of Peter Pratt's Inn, an
historic landmark. Applebome, Peter. "[http://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpag-
e.html?res=9A00E6DE1E3FF930A35756C0A9609C8B63 Fill It Up, Please, and Check for
Clogged Arteries]". [[New York Times]]. May 3, 2006. Reed, M.H.
"[http://www.prattsinn.com/reviews5.html Steeped in the Past, Looking to the
Future]". [[New York Times]]. September 30, 2007. According to James
Pratt, founder of the event, while the original event hosted only eight people
interested in discussing alternatives to gas, each successive incarnation of the
Greasestock celebration has drawn more and more visitors from all over the
United States who are interested in cheaper gas, cleaner energy, and helping the
environment. "[http://video.aol.com/video-detail/fill-er-up-with-
canola/1552127871 Fill 'er up with canola]". [[ABC News]]. May 19, 2008.

The green technologies demonstrated at the event include vegetable oil powered
cars, biodiesel cars, solar powered cars, home heating alternatives, and organic
farming exhibits. "[http://www.greasestock.org/images/GreasestockMay08.jpg
Greasestock 2008: Alternative Fuel, Fun and French Fries]".
[http://www.naturalawakeningsmag.com/ Natural Awakenings]. May 2008. The
event draws exhibitors from all over the United States, and included among the
hundred or so vehicles on display is a vegetable powered garbage truck from
Mamaroneck, New York, the first of its kind in New York, which saved the
municipality around $10,000 per year on fuel costs. Golodryga, Bianna and
Hoffman, Jessica. "[http://abcnews.go.com/GMA/Springtime/story?id=4884738
Greasestock Celebrates Alternative Fuel]". [[ABC News]]. May 19, 2008.

The "Veggie Van", a project of V.O. Tech Inc. of Mahpoac, New York and the
Westchester County Government, is one of the exhibits at the Greasestock
event. [http://video.wnbc.com/player/?id=160472 'Veggie Van' pushes for
cleaner environment]". [[NBC News]]. September 19, 2007. The van gets its
fuel from a local restaurant, and the food filtered out of the vegetable oil is
used as compost at the County's Hanover Farm in Yorktown, New
York. "[http://www.westchestergov.com/news_veggievan.htm Veggie Van Unveiled
(Press Release)]". [[Westchester County, New York|Westchestergov.com]].
September 19, 2007. "[http://www.wcbs880.com/Westchester-Unveils-the--Veggie-Van-
/967997 Westchester Unveils the 'Veggie Van']". [[WCBS 880]]. September 19,
2007.
categories: Visitor attractions in Westchester County, New York
